title: 114_s1990
content: The Act is titled the "Federal Computer Security Act" and includes definitions for key terms. The "Federal Computer Security Act" defines key terms such as agency, covered agency, logical access control, and multi-factor logical access controls. The "Federal Computer Security Act" defines multi-factor logical access controls as a set of at least 2 of the following: user information, access device, or unique biometric characteristic. SEC. 3. Inspector General report on federal computer systems. Inspector Generals of covered agencies must submit a report to the Comptroller General and relevant committees within 240 days of the Act's enactment. The report should include information on Federal computer systems, specifically logical access standards for classified or personally identifiable information. The report from Inspector Generals of covered agencies must include a description of logical access standards used to access Federal computer systems with classified or personally identifiable information, including details on access controls and the use of multi-factor authentication. If logical access controls are not used, reasons for this decision must be provided. The covered agency must provide a description of data security management practices, including conducting software inventories and licensing agreements for software security controls. The covered agency must report on software inventories, licenses for security controls, and usage of data protection software. If not using such software, reasons must be provided. The covered agency must report on software inventories, licenses for security controls, and usage of data protection software. If not using such software, reasons must be provided along with descriptions of policies for ensuring data security management practices by entities providing services to the agency. The report may be based on audits or evaluations related to agency programs and can be included in other reports. The agency must report on data security management practices as described in paragraph (3). The report may be based on audits or evaluations related to agency programs and can be included in other reports. Reports must be unclassified but may include a classified annex and must be made available to Members of Congress upon request. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to Congress within a year of this Act's enactment, analyzing impediments to agency use of security software and devices. The report may include a classified annex but must be in unclassified form.
